mentions.context: In GeoLifeCLEF 2020, [27] used this approach to train a model from scratch using most modalities available.

The final GeoLifeCLEF 2022 dataset consists of 1,663,996 observations covering 17,037 plants and animal species distributed across US (975,357 observations, 14,135 species) and France (688,539 observations, 4,858 species), as shown in Figure 2. The number of observations of each species is not uniform and follows a long-tail distribution shown in Figure 3.
The 2022 edition of GeoLifeCLEF has shown a growing interest from the machine learning community towards the challenge.

In the first two editions, GeoLifeCLEF 2018 [3] and GeoLifeCLEF 2019 [4], each observation was associated only with environmental features given as vectors or patches extracted around the observation.
This competition is the fifth GeoLifeCLEF challenge.
To the best of our knowledge, GeoLifeCLEF dataset is the largest publicly available dataset to pair remote sensing imagery with species observations.

Like the two last year's campaigns (GeoLifeCLEF 2020 [5] and GeoLifeCLEF 2021 [6]), GeoLifeCLEF 2022 is aimed at bridging the previously mentioned gaps by (i) sharing a large-scale dataset of observations paired with high-resolution covariates and (ii) defining a common evaluation methodology to measure the predictive performance of models trained on this dataset.
A detailed description of the original GeoLifeCLEF 2020 dataset is provided in [7].

In this work, we present the results of the GeoLifeCLEF 2022 competition which is part of the LifeCLEF evaluation campaign [2] and co-hosted in Ninth Workshop on Fine-Grained Visual Categorization (FGVC9) 1 at CVPR 2022.
This approach has been successfully applied during GeoLifeCLEF 2021 [28] and was yet again used for GeoLifeCLEF 2022 by top teams Sensio Team (winning solution), EPFL and UdeM / Mila.

In the first two editions, GeoLifeCLEF 2018 [3] and GeoLifeCLEF 2019 [4], each observation was associated only with environmental features given as vectors or patches extracted around the observation.

Like the two last year's campaigns (GeoLifeCLEF 2020 [5] and GeoLifeCLEF 2021 [6]), GeoLifeCLEF 2022 is aimed at bridging the previously mentioned gaps by (i) sharing a large-scale dataset of observations paired with high-resolution covariates and (ii) defining a common evaluation methodology to measure the predictive performance of models trained on this dataset.
10% of those observations were used for the public leaderboard on Kaggle while the remaining 90% allowed to compute the private leaderboard providing the final results of the challenge.
Figure 7 summarizes the main architectures tested in the course of GeoLifeCLEF 2022 to aggregate the different modalities.
52 teams participated and submitted at least one prediction file through the Kaggle8 page of the GeoLifeCLEF 2022 challenge for a total number of submissions in the course of the competition of 261.
The training and test data were publicly shared on 9th March 2022 through the Kaggle platform 6 .
To advance research in this area, a large-scale machine learning competition called GeoLifeCLEF 2022 was organized.

Like the two last year's campaigns (GeoLifeCLEF 2020 [5] and GeoLifeCLEF 2021 [6]), GeoLifeCLEF 2022 is aimed at bridging the previously mentioned gaps by (i) sharing a large-scale dataset of observations paired with high-resolution covariates and (ii) defining a common evaluation methodology to measure the predictive performance of models trained on this dataset.
52 teams participated and submitted at least one prediction file through the Kaggle8 page of the GeoLifeCLEF 2022 challenge for a total number of submissions in the course of the competition of 261.
This approach has been successfully applied during GeoLifeCLEF 2021 [28] and was yet again used for GeoLifeCLEF 2022 by top teams Sensio Team (winning solution), EPFL and UdeM / Mila.

As the winners did not submit a working notes paper but described their method in the "Discussion" tab on the Kaggle page of the competition 12 , we summarize it here for archiving and referencing purposes.
• CNN on 3-channels patches: a ResNet-50 [17] convolution neural network (CNN) trained on the high-resolution 256 × 256 patches using PyTorch [18].
Different approaches for model pre-training were also tested: no pre-training, pre-training on ImageNet, and pre-training on another dataset closer to GeoLifeCLEF 2022 (by UdeM / Mila).

These did not help improve their scores, most likely because the test set shares the same imbalance as the training set and the evaluation metric did take it into account (the fixed list of metrics implemented by Kaggle did not allow us to use a class-averaged top-30 error rate).
